INTRODUCTION

In response to the requirements of Federal EPA, this Risk Management Plan has been developed for the Cliffside Steam Station (CSS) located in Cliffside, NC.  CSS is owned and operated by Duke Energy.

PLANT AND PROCESS INFORMATION

CSS has installed a new anhydrous ammonia system as a component supporting selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of the plant's boiler emissions.  Ammonia vapor (in the presence of the SCR catalyst) reduces NOx compounds to elemental nitrogen and water to reduce the total NOx effluent emitted from the plant.

The anhydrous ammonia system is comprised of two storage tanks, each with a capacity of 45,000 gallons, along with feed pumps and vaporizing equipment.  The two tanks will be administratively controlled such that their aggregate capacity will not exceed 80,000 gallons.  The total quantity of ammonia exceeds threshold quantities which invoke the requirements of the Risk Management regulations.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION MEASURES

CSS is committed to public safety, employee safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance.  Based on this commitment, the Regional Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program.  A management system has been developed with clearly defined accountability and responsibility for the Risk Management Program.

To help ensure that any serious chemical releases do not occur, CSS maintains a release prevention program which is focused on protecting the public and plant employees from the hazards associated with an accident or release involving ammonia.  This multifaceted program includes the use of:

Ammmonia gas detection and alarms to rapidly alert operators to any problems;

Process instrumentation and interlocks which will shutdown the system and isolate ammonia supplies to the plant if process conditions (such as flow, temperature, and pressure) are not within their appropriate safe operating ranges;

Process safety info

emergency response team on-site with the appropriate number of members, training, and equipment to actively respond to and take action necessary to secure credible releases of ammonia that might occur.  Additionally, there are a number of emergency operations procedures in place which detail the appropriate emergency actions that would help mitigate the effects of releases.

MAINTAINING A SAFE OPERATION

Duke Energy and Cliffside Steam Station will continually work to safely manage the hazards of the ammonia system to protect the communities we serve and the employees, vendors and visitors at the station.  The Risk Management Program will be maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases through training, procedures, equipment maintenance, and safe work practices.  Periodically, CSS will audit the program, review the Process Hazard Analysis, coordinate wth community emergency response organizations, and will update the program as needed to assure safe and efficient control and management of the anhydrous ammonia system.
